channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Hadiran CEO Power Speaks on Re-Shoring High Skill Labor
item.description: Hadrian CEO Chris Power speaks at the Reagan National Economic Forum in California on re-industrialization and the re-shoring of high skill labor. He says you "have to automate" due to the lack of high skill laborers, but when automation and AI cannot do the job, a highly productive workforce is important. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Says He’ll Increase US Steel Import Tariffs to 50%
item.description: President Donald Trump announces that he would increase tariffs on steel to 50% from 25% to help protect American steelworkers during a visit to a United States Steel Corp. plant.

item.title: Costco Defies Tariff Volatility as Other Retailers Stumble
item.description:
Costco Wholesale Corp. posted better-than-expected earnings in the third quarter, a sign that the nation’s largest club chain is flexing its scale and devoted following to navigate tariffs and other forces of economic turbulence.
The retailer said it generated earnings per share of $4.28 for the quarter ended May 11, above what Wall Street analysts were expecting. The metric suggests that Costco is growing its business even as consumers prioritize necessities to save money.
Burt Flickinger, Managing Director of Strategic Resource Group, reacts to Costco's earnings and examines the health of other key players in the retail sector, including Walmart, The Gap and Ulta Beauty. Burt speaks with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Patrick Collison Speaks: It's Not the Internet's Fault
item.description: Stripe co-founder and CEO Patrick Collison speaks at the Reagan National Economic Forum in California on coding advancements in recent history. He says "the reason for the stasis in the domain of atoms" cannot be blamed on the advancements in the world of bits, and that "it's not the internet's fault." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump on US Steel: ‘We Saved the Company’
item.description: “We have the hottest nation anywhere in the world,” President Donald Trump says while celebrating the Nippon Steel-US Steel deal.

item.title: Next-Gen Crypto Funds That Offer Rewards Beckon After SEC Signal
item.description: A new generation of crypto ETFs that allow investors to earn yield — not just bet on prices — looked poised for their Wall Street debut.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Lee

media:content.media:description: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 10, 2024. The SEC's X account was compromised and a fake post claiming that the agency had green lit plans for a spot-Bitcoin exchange-traded fund fueled a brief surge in the price of the world's biggest cryptocurrency.

item.title: Japan Seeks to Grow Africa Investments to Ease Reliance on China
item.description: Japan is supporting its companies to grow their business in Africa and develop trade ties across a continent where it’s mainly been seen as a key donor.
item.dc:creator: Yinka Ibukun

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk between office buildings in the Central Business District (CBD) of Lagos, Nigeria, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. Nigerian President Bola Tinubu has declared a state of emergency to counter the rising cost of living and in early August announced a 500 billion naira package of measures to improve food supply, ease transportation costs and boost manufacturing.

item.title: NY Proposes a ConEd Revenue Increase 80% Below Utility’s Request
item.description: New York’s utility regulator proposed a revenue increase for Consolidated Edison Inc. that’s 80% below the utility’s request as sensitivity over consumer power bills mounts.
item.dc:creator: Josh Saul, Mark Chediak

media:content.media:description: A Con Edison worker in the East Village neighborhood of New York, US, on Saturday, Aug. 10, 2024. Initial applications for US unemployment benefits fell by the most in nearly a year, potentially alleviating some concerns that the labor market is cooling too fast following a disappointing jobs report earlier this month.

item.title: US Treasuries Post First Monthly Loss of 2025 on Deficit Woes
item.description: US Treasuries are delivering their first monthly loss this year, buffeted by renewed tariff uncertainty and growing anxiety over mounting levels of government debt.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Sujata Rao

media:content.media:description: The Times Square neighborhood of New York. Photographer: Yuki Iwamura/Bloomberg

item.title: Ayesha Curry's Commitment to Using Her Platform to Build Strong Communities
item.description: Ayesha Curry, author, entrepreneur, and philanthropist, and Hali Lee, Author of “The Big We” discuss the future of Sweet July Books and the importance of starting a new paradigm of charitable giving. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fintech Chime Is Said to Plan IPO Launch as Soon as Monday
item.description: Chime Financial Inc. is planning to launch its initial public offering as soon as Monday, according to people familiar with the matter, as US listings bounce back from a disappointing April.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes, Ryan Gould

media:content.media:description: The Chime logo appears on a smartphone screen in this illustration photo in Reno, United States, on December 24, 2024. (Photo by via Getty Images)

item.title: Pursuing AI Growth Opportunities
item.description: Patrick McGoldrick, managing partner at JPMorgan Private Capital’s Growth Equity Partners, discusses opportunities in AI investing and when he thinks exits will pick up. McGoldrick joins Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P 500 Whipsaws at End of Best May Since 1990: Markets Wrap
item.description: Volatility gripped stocks in the last stretch of the month, with the market bouncing from its lows as Donald Trump said he expected to speak to Xi Jinping after accusing China of a trade-deal breach.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Opportunities in Agentic Automation
item.description: Daniel Dines, CEO of UiPath, discusses the company's earnings and where the automation software developer sees growth opportunities. He speaks with Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Smartphone Manufacturing Is a 'Dream': IDC's Popal
item.description: Smartphone manufacturing in the US is a “dream,” says Nabila Popal, IDC senior research director. She discusses her research with Ed Ludlow on "Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: NYC Bitcoin-Bond Idea Squashed by Lander as ‘Irresponsible’
item.description: New York City Comptroller Brad Lander poured cold water on Mayor Eric Adams’s proposal to issue municipal bonds backed by Bitcoin.
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie, Martin Z Braun

media:content.media:description: New York City Comptroller Brad Lander in New York.

item.title: Saks Reveals $100 Million Loss in No-Questions Creditor Call
item.description: Saks Global Enterprises told creditors it had an adjusted loss of more than $100 million last fiscal year, one day after it announced a $350 million financial lifeline ahead of a looming coupon payment.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Ronalds-Hannon, Reshmi Basu, Irene Garcia Perez

media:content.media:description: A Neiman Marcus store in Garden City, New York, US, on Friday, July 5, 2024. The owner of Saks Fifth Avenue is acquiring Neiman Marcus Group for $2.65 billion, a deal that will unite America's two largest high-end department-store chains in a bid to grab a bigger share of a slowing industry.

item.title: Wall Street’s Macro Traders Get Schooled in Trump-Era Turbulence
item.description: For anyone on Wall Street still clinging to a time-honored macro-investing playbook, Trump 2.0 has been a source of endless punishment.
item.dc:creator: Lu Wang, Denitsa Tsekova

media:content.media:description: A Make America Great Again hat on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Morgan Stanley Sees ‘Uncomfortable’ Rally in Emerging Markets
item.description: Emerging-market assets should keep rallying for the rest of the year, but gains will likely be limited by a slowing global economy and US policy uncertainty, according to Morgan Stanley.
item.dc:creator: Vinicius Andrade

item.title: S&P 500 Has Muted Close After Tariff Headlines Whipsaw Traders
item.description: US stocks climbed from session lows to end Friday little changed as President Donald Trump said he expected to speak to Chinese President Xi Jinping after accusing China of violating a trade truce between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: BASF Kicks Off €6 Billion Sale of Coatings Business
item.description: BASF SE has kicked off a sale of its coatings business, in a process that could value the unit at about €6 billion ($6.8 billion) and attract bids from large buyout firms, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Dinesh Nair, Eyk Henning, Swetha Gopinath, Pamela Barbaglia

media:content.media:description: Flags at an entrance to the BASF SE chemical plant in Ludwigshafen, Germany, on Tuesday, April 25, 2023. BASF SE reported mixed preliminary first-quarter results, with higher-than-expected operating profit and revenue that missed analyst expectations after rising energy costs reduced the company’s output. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Robson, Toublan on Economic Data, Yields, Foreign Buyers
item.description: As US Treasuries are set for the first month of loss of 2025, BNP Paribas Head of US Credit Strategy Meghan Robson says the tariffs uncertainty will be impactful to the negative side of growth. Barclays Head of US Credit Strategy Dominique Toublan says uncertainty does not give consumers or businesses much confidence to make big plans for the future. They speak with Vonnie Quinn on "Real Yield." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: S&P, Nasdaq Log Best Month Since 2023 | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Jess Menton. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Blackstone Lowers Offer for Warehouse REIT, Extends Deadline
item.description: Funds managed by Blackstone Inc. have lowered an offer to purchase Warehouse REIT Plc after matters uncovered in due diligence made a previous bid unworkable, according to a statement.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Wong

media:content.media:description: The Blackstone headquarters in in New York, US, on Wednesday, July 17, 2024. Blackstone Inc.'s real estate arm weighed on the investment giant’s second-quarter results, as high interest rates crimped property valuations and investors pumped less money into the business. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Dollar Notches Its Longest Monthly Losing Streak Since 2020
item.description: A few days of gains for the US dollar this week wasn’t enough to reverse its broader declines as US trade and policy uncertainty weighs on sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis, Anya Andrianova

media:content.media:description: A US dollar sign on a glass in the trading room at foreign exchange brokerage Gaitame.Com Co. in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, June 24, 2024. The yen remained under pressure on Monday, even after Japan’s top currency official warned that authorities stand ready to intervene in currency markets 24 hours a day if necessary. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Hedge Funds Rush Into Oil Short Bets as OPEC Supply Risk Looms
item.description: Hedge funds loaded up on the most bearish bets against Brent crude since October as the market braced for a fresh injection of OPEC+ supply.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis

item.title: Trump College Attack Hurts Innovation: Ex-Education Sec.
item.description: President Donald Trump’s efforts to strip major US universities of federal funding will lead to a loss of top talent and regression in innovation, according to former Education Secretary John King Jr. He speaks with Bloomberg’s Dani Burger.

item.title: Alberta Wildfires Approach Oil Sands, Threaten More Output
item.description: Wildfires in Alberta are threatening almost half a million barrels of daily crude production as heat and wind push the flames closer to massive oil sands well sites.
item.dc:creator: Robert Tuttle, Lauren Rosenthal

media:content.media:description: oil sands near Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada, on Monday, Sept. 10, 2018.

item.title: Time to Brace for the 'TACO' Impact
item.description: Trump will do anything to prove he’s not chicken. Brace for the TACO impact, says Bloomberg Opinion’s Timothy L. O’Brien. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Deficits Are Here To Stay a While: Charles Schwab's Martin
item.description: US Treasuries are on track to deliver their first monthly loss this year, buffeted by renewed tariff uncertainty and growing anxiety over mounting levels of government debt. Charles Schwab Fixed Income Strategist Collin Martin recommends focusing on the belly of the curve and Goldman Sachs Asset Management Head of Multi Sector Fixed Income Lindsay Rosner says the US has depth that other markets don't and that will encourage investors to seek out US assets, particularly treasuries. (Source: Bloomberg)
